articles.headline: Appeals Court Panel Throws Out Class Action Over Light Cigarettes
articles.snippet: In a victory for the tobacco industry, a federal appeals court threw out on Thursday an $800 billion class-action lawsuit on behalf of smokers who said they had been misled that light cigarettes were safer than regular ones.
articles.abstract: In a victory for the tobacco industry, a federal appeals court threw out on Thursday an $800 billion class-action lawsuit on behalf of smokers who said they had been misled that light cigarettes were safer than regular ones.

articles.headline: At Hearing, Pointed Questions About What Led to a Bailout
articles.snippet: Senate hearings got underway on Thursday over the role of the government in Bear Stearns’s collapse.
articles.abstract: Senate hearings got underway on Thursday over the role of the government in Bear Stearns’s collapse.
articles.lead_paragraph: “I love the ritual,” growled Robert S. Bennett, the influential Washington lawyer as he sucked on a lozenge. He eyed the clutch of photographers swarming around Federal Reserve Chairman Ben S. Bernanke, the clicking of shutters rising up like a storm of insects in the committee room.

articles.headline: 81% in Poll Say Nation Is Headed on Wrong Track
articles.snippet: Americans are more dissatisfied with the country’s direction than at any time since the the early 1990s.
articles.abstract: Americans are more dissatisfied with the country’s direction than at any time since the the early 1990s.
articles.lead_paragraph: Americans are more dissatisfied with the country’s direction than at any time since the New York Times/CBS News poll began asking about the subject in the early 1990s, according to the latest poll.
articles.byline: By David Leonhardt and Marjorie Connelly

articles.headline: New Signs of Mugabe Crackdown in Zimbabwe
articles.snippet: Police officers loyal to Robert G. Mugabe raided opposition offices and arrested two foreign journalists in their hotel.
articles.abstract: Police officers loyal to Robert G. Mugabe raided opposition offices and arrested two foreign journalists in their hotel.
articles.lead_paragraph: Zimbabwe’s government staged separate police raids on Thursday against the main opposition party, foreign journalists and at least one democracy advocate, raising the specter of a broad crackdown aimed at keeping the country’s imperiled leaders in power.

articles.abstract: Market opportunists are buying up the mortgages of hard-pressed homeowners and companies.

articles.headline: Testimony Offers Details of Bear Stearns Deal
articles.snippet: Federal officials and senior Wall Street executives offered their first public account on Thursday of the harrowing four days of negotiations.
articles.abstract: Federal officials and senior Wall Street executives offered their first public account on Thursday of the harrowing four days of negotiations.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Three weeks after the market crisis that forced the rescue of Bear Stearns, federal officials and senior Wall Street executives offered their first public account on Thursday of the harrowing four days of negotiations that led to a deal to sell the investment bank to JPMorgan Chase.

articles.headline: Three Record Companies Team Up With MySpace for Music Web Site
articles.snippet: Three of the music industry’s four major companies have struck a deal with the social networking site MySpace to start a music Web site.
articles.abstract: Three of the music industry’s four major companies have struck a deal with the social networking site MySpace to start a music Web site.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  In the latest effort by the ailing music industry to bolster its declining prospects, three of the industry’s four major companies have struck a deal with the social networking site MySpace to start a music Web site.
articles.byline: By Jeff Leeds and Brad Stone

articles.headline: More Than 1,000 in Iraq’s Forces Quit Basra Fight
articles.snippet: Desertions in the heat of a major battle cast fresh doubt on the effectiveness of Iraqi security forces.
articles.abstract: Desertions in the heat of a major battle cast fresh doubt on the effectiveness of Iraqi security forces.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  More than 1,000 Iraqi soldiers and policemen either refused to fight or simply abandoned their posts during the inconclusive assault against Shiite militias in Basra last week, a senior Iraqi government official said Thursday. Iraqi military officials said the group included dozens of officers, including at least two senior field commanders in the battle.
articles.byline: By Stephen Farrell and James Glanz
